awd_titl_txt: Determining hillslope-scale material strength from seismically-triggered landslide events
awd_abstract_narration:
A non-technical description of the project, which explains the project's significance and importance

Landslides are a continual threat in many mountainous regions of the world and the danger is increased in areas prone to large earthquakes. In spite of this association, knowledge concerning the extent to which seismic events can trigger landslides is rudimentary. This project will examine data from the 1994 Northridge, California earthquake in order to evaluate how lithology, tectonics, rock strength, and fracture density influence the susceptibility of hillslopes to landslides. Data will be entered into a model that was developed as a pilot test for the 2008 Wenchuan earthquake in China. The more detailed and field-checked results from the California earthquake will permit refinement of the model and engender a wider applicability for hazard assessments in other areas. In particular, the data will be incorporated into a program of the U.S. Geological Survey, which is developing an automated system that produces estimates of impact and losses for earthquakes around the world for emergency response, government and aid agencies, and the media. Advances resulting from this project will aid in their implementation.

A technical description of the project

Natural hillslope strength, which is a major controlling factor for landscape evolution and hazard assessment, is usually quite different than measurements of rock strength on hand-sized samples done in the laboratory. Laboratory tests are performed on intact rock, yet it is fracture density, aperture, and size that determine hillslope-scale rock strength.  The strength of hillslopes can be quantified by using large seismic events in high relief settings, where an earthquake causes strong ground motion (peak ground acceleration) and a quantifiable landscape response (landsliding). This project assesses slope stability as a function of landslide thickness and shear-strength properties (cohesion and internal angle of friction) for a particular seismic event using modeled peak ground acceleration.  The research focuses on landslides caused by the 1994 magnitude 6.7 Northridge earthquake, where it is hypothesized that tectonic deformation causes a strength reduction of hillslopes that can be isolated from lithologic and climatic factors. The project will integrate modeling and fieldwork to test this hypothesis and the results will improve knowledge of tectonic processes as a governor of rock weakening. The findings are relevant to earth surface processes, landscape evolution, tectonics, and natural-hazard assessment.

por.por_cntn:
Rock strength has long been recognized as a major control on landscape morphology and evolution. Because strength governs the ability of material to be dislodged and transported by surface processes, it contributes to feedbacks between tectonics, climate, and surface processes in mountain belts. Despite recognition of this general concept, many factors that control rock strength are poorly quantified at watershed to mountain belt scales. Understanding the interdependences of factors that control rock strength is of broad interest because it applies to hillslope stability (landslides), weathering, erosion and sediment transport on hillslopes and in channels, and rates at which landscapes evolve over geologic time. 

Measuring rock strength at spatial scales relevant for geomorphic investigations remains an outstanding challenge due to the scale-dependent nature of strength. While laboratory tests of rock strength are conducted on intact hand-sized samples, we know that fractures and discontinuities in a rock mass set the upper limit on strength at larger scales applicable to landscapes. Consequently, laboratory tests can overestimate hillslope-scale strength by an order of magnitude. The purpose of this award was to take develop and refine novel methods for extracting strength information at geomorphically-relevant spatial scales, and to use these and complementary field data to assess the specific role of tectonic fracturing on rock mass strength.

Significant outcomes of this research included developing and testing two approaches to quantifying rock mass strength based on slope stability models, digital topography and co-seismic landslide inventories. The first approach uses hillslope morphology extracted from digital elevation models to estimate strength based on a 2D model of hillslope stability, and may be generally exportable to other settings as a way to quantify rock strength from topography. The second approach leverages earthquake-driven landslide inventories as a means to invert for rock strength properties using a dynamic model in which the forces from strong ground motion cause landsliding. 

Another major component of this research included inclusion of field data that could be used to compare to the regional scale slope stability models. The effect of discontinuities on rock mass strength can be captured from outcrops using field observations coupled with ranked classification schemes (e.g. GSI, Hoek and Brown method) that penalize intact rock strength by the density, orientation, and surface conditions of fractures. We complemented the surface observations with shallow seismic subsurface data using the MASW technique for measuring S-wave velocity profiles to depths of 20-40 m. In general, the spatial distribution afforded by all of these methods allowed us to quantify rock strength across a tectonic gradient in the Topatopa Mountains, where differences in fault motion exposed sedimentary rocks with variable burial and exhumation histories. Our results show similar trends in strength with respect to stratigraphic position and have comparable strength estimates to the lowest values of published direct-shear test data. We found that maximum burial depth exerts the strongest control on the strength of these young sedimentary rocks, likely through diagenetic changes in porosity, cementation, and ultimately, lithification.

We also found a positive relationship between both model and field measurements of rock strength, and fault-driven erosion rates from new geochemical data, wherein strength increases with increasing erosion rate. We suggest that this relationship is a function of decreasing residence time in the Critical Zone (CZ), the uppermost layers of regolith and soil on Earth?s surface. Weakening of intact bedrock occurs due to physical and chemical weathering as a parcel of rock is transported from depth to the surface, and we find that the rate of exhumation has a direct influence on resultant rock mass strength. Recognition of this relationship between rock strength and tectonics provides further insight into the competing controls on mountain belt morphology and evolution, and may be indicative of a feedback wherein rock mass strength increases with increasing uplift rate and partially contributes to the growth of relief in mountain ranges. 

The project fostered collaborations with Dr. Sean Gallen at Colorado State University, Dr. Nathan Niemi at the University of Michigan, Dr. Dimitrios Zekkos at University of Berkeley, and Dr. Francis Rengers at the Landslide Hazards Program within the Natural Hazards Mission Area of the US Geological Survey. Several students were also trained as a part of this award, including one PhD student and several undergraduate students from the University of Michigan. Research outcomes have been communicated in two journal articles that are currently under review, one article that is to be submitted prior to summer 2020, at scientific conferences, and through public release of a landslide dataset.
